sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of travel outcome occurring on a trip
message_1: A group of 10 friends plan to go on a road trip. The probability that each friend will bring a backpack is 0.8. What is the probability that exactly 7 of the friends will bring a backpack?
message_2:
We can solve this problem using the binomial probability formula:

P(x) = C(n, x) * p^x * (1-p)^(n-x)

where:
- P(x) is the probability of exactly x successes (in this case, friends bringing a backpack)
- C(n, x) is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time (also written as nCx or "n choose x")
- n is the total number of trials (in this case, the number of friends, which is 10)
- x is the number of successful trials (in this case, the number of friends bringing a backpack, which is 7)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, the probability of a friend bringing a backpack, which is 0.8)
- (1-p) is the probability of failure (in this case, the probability of a friend not bringing a backpack, which is 0.2)

Plugging in the values, we get:

P(7) = C(10, 7) * 0.8^7 * 0.2^3

First, we need to find C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 friends out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = (10 * 9 * 8) / (3 * 2 * 1)
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, we can plug this value back into the formula:

P(7) = 120 * 0.8^7 * 0.2^3
P(7) ≈ 120 * 0.2097152 * 0.008
P(7) ≈ 0.201326592

So, the probability that exactly 7 of the friends will bring a backpack is approximately 0.201 or 20.1%.
